values: Somewhere there's a darkly creative seed from these three songs. Yes the lyrics are meant to be like that. Disjointed displacement fits this seed. Skinny Puppy - Choralone video Choralone: Sets the mood and the setting. Convulsion: Complication, drive. Grave Wisdom: Resolution. I found videos for Convulsion but they did not fit what my brain was producing and/or were too nauseating. No video for Grave Wisdom, which was the initial spark. The Choralone video is best viewed with contrast left as is or darker and the window size kept the same. Like most Skinny Puppy videos the less you clearly perceive the better, and the mind fills in crudities or gaps with much creepier imagery. In this video, used as a backdrop during a tour, the crude animations become rythmically surreal, leaping nightmares loping forward on the unnatural beat. Mockeries of life, aberrations of fears. Hunting, fleeing, dancing, on, off.
The other coda. Stigmata. Possible lyrics. Ministry is never known for having really decipherable vocals, one thing Nine Inch Nails was much better at from the start.

When Men Were Men & Pigs Were Money. (rules tagline) Last night I'd talked about H.G. Wells' Little Wars* with a friend and this morning felt like playing a light skirmish game before breakfast. Settled upon a set I'd never played through, Pig Wars - Dark Age Skirmish, since it only needs under 20 figures a side, a small space, and a deck of cards. It also doesn't require terrain. I scrambled together a rough post-Roman band of hairy barbarians and a small Byzantine group guarding a priest and an acolyte holding a Holy Book. Later I named it the Holy Book of Simeon of Antioch, as a nod to Monty Python's Holy Hand Grenade of Antioch and Simeon Stylites, a saint local to Antioch. Setup: the Hairy Sub-Romans came across the Byzantines transporting the Book of Simeon of Antioch on its way to its new home. Plunder of Constantinople's recounquest of the West. The gilded and bejeweled book would be a good prize and the priest & acoylte would make a high price in ransom. Badric ordered his archers and young tribesmen on the left while he formed up on the right with his picked men. Locking shields in the center the Gothic types tramped forward. Facing them was Narsius, veteran of battles in Italy & Sicily, a handful of his champions, and some thematic (conscripted) troops from Asia Minor. His two archers were on the right, facing their counterparts while he and his champions were at intervals in the line of shields he formed around him. A few troops were placed behind to plug holes in the line or protect the priests behind the line as needed. One champion was placed behind the archers. In front he placed his two javelinmen to tie down and hopefully break up the shield wall as it advanced. The Battle: The Sub-Roman archers opened a hole on the Byzantine right, scattering the Byzantine archers as the young tribesmen poured in while Badric and his men charged the Byzantine left. The shieldwall was held up by the Byzantine javelinmen who were slowly cut down. The axemen on the Byzantine left cut through the Byzantine line until reinforcements cut them down as the Byzantine champion on the right rallied the crumbling line there until he was cut down by arrowfire. Finally the Sub-Roman shieldwall hit their Byzantine counterparts but were hurled back dying or dead. With Badric's shieldwall down and his young tribesmen being pushed back by Byzantine spears, Badric and his picked men surged towards Narsius to either rout the Byzantines or die with glory. They whittled down Narsius' champions around him, falling as they advanced until Badric alone was face to face with Narsius. They clashed, Badric taking out more foes until a Byzantine soldier got behind and stuck him like a pig. The only remaining Sub-Romans were the archers, who spitefully managed to kill the acolyte holding the Holy Book and left a few arrows in the book before running from the field of battle. The priest gained some holes in his robes. I didn't get to use the game's wonderful looting chart sadly. Result: So the Holy Book was saved, but only Narsius, 5 Thematic Troops, and the Priest (now with a holey Holy Book) were left standing. All done and put away before breakfast on a rainy morning. Analysis: I went through the deck twice and not having to keep a roster sheet or roll dice with a lot of modifers was very nice. For initive a red card meant the Byzantines went first, black the Sub-Romans. The Sub-Romans get the initive twice after the Byzantines got it the first turn. Shooting is opposed if a hit is scored based on armour type, melee is opposed card draws, with weapon type & tactical factors being added to a total. Kills are scored based on compared margins. With the rain continuing and tomorrow a holiday, I think i'll try some Colonial Wargamming using The Sword & The Flame rules before Sunday dinner. Need to do some cleaning anyway, and making room for a game is a great incentive! See comments for unit lists and figure manufacturers. Pig Wars is by Tod Kershner, author of the deadly Age of Reason rules. * arguably the ancestor of modern miniature gaming and by extension roleplaying, last night with a friend. Wells used toy cannon to literally fire & knock over toy soldiers with melee being 1:1. Fun, diceless, and cardless. As Wells posits, it would be better if wars were fought this way and people learned of wars deadliness in this way first!

The core of the new Runequest rules by Mongoose / Greg Stafford et al for free. A new take on the original game that inspired BRP. ^__^ I haven't seen the printed book, as I wanted to check out the free SRD first. From a skim it looks like the SRD is complete enough to use by itself, esp. if combined with any BRP core book or the Call of Cthulhu quickstart rules linked below. And yes, it has ducks in it. QVACK! .DOC: http://www.mongoosepublishing.com/pdf/rqsrd.zip PDF: http://myweb.cableone.net/JJVargas/Runequest%20SRD%20Complete.pdf HTML: http://www.darkshire.net/~jhkim/rpg/srd/srd_runic/ Zipped HTML: http://www.darkshire.net/~jhkim/rpg/srd/srd_runic/runic_srd.zip Signs & Portents 35 has a free adventure for MRQ, A Raven in the Roost. Direct download. So check it out! Now for Chaosium to come out with Deluxe BRP. For comparison with stock BRP, check out Chaosium's Call of Cthulhu Quickstart Rules PDF (B&W / Color). first spotted here: http://www.rpgblog.org/rpg_blog/2006/08/runequest_srd_n.html

Lee Presson & the Nails are returning this September, as the reichmarshall, Lee Presson himself, recently announced! So if you happen to be near the DNA Lounge in San Francisco on September 16th check out Kingfish & Eddie's Hubba Hubba revue. Lee Presson & the Nails (also known as Lee Press-On & the Nails or LPN) are kinda like the Addams Family on swing via Oingo Boingo with a dash of Nine Inch Nails. Darkly fun dancing music. Playing Dirty: LPN live at the Derby is the best single cd though they're all good. Samples here. "Enjoy yourself, it's later than you think
Enjoy yourself, while you're still in the pink
The years go by, as quickly as a wink
Enjoy yourself, enjoy yourself, it's later than you think"
- from the version by LPN

Podcast Byzantine Rulers: The History of The Byzantine Empire http://www.anders.com/lectures/lars_brownworth/12_byzantine_rulers/ The Byzantium Empire, as named after its fall, the continuation of the Roman Empire in the East, is best known for the adjective Byzantine. It's far more than just that as well as an entertaining story, and this podcast is an accessible way to learn more. It was a major force in the Dark Ages/Middle Ages (for culture, learning, political, military, & economic power, and for relgion) and was still around until the early Renaissance. Well worth another look. The podcaster, Lars Brownwor, reads in a fairly even voice and the material is rich enough that I don't fall asleep to the podcast. The website supplements the podcast with additional commentaries, answers to questions, and more information on Byzantium, sources, and the podcaster. While I recommend listening to them in order, for a sample try podcasts one, and then three through five. Seven through nine are great, but really need some grounding from the earlier podcasts. See comments for the boring stuff.

So Spacemusic hosted by *TC* live from Rotterdam, The Netherlands, is coming back! Soacemusic is a ambient music podcast, and will now be through iStream, worth a checksee. Great background music, and better than Hearts of Space these days. TC's a great host and often includes little snippets of what he's doing or cooking up for the evening. Great intro and bumper music too. For a sample of the type of music TC selects, download i realize by rymdlego. I never tire of this song, so pleasant and soothing. First heard in Spacemusic#30 Deep Dish Delight.

The Residents one minute shorts Okay, so Joy by Yuki isn't *quite* a female j-pop The Residents. In my defence I'd not actually seen a video by The Residents in...over 15 years and never really saw much of them beyond the publicity photos and album covers. They were *not* MTV material. :) How to describe them and their music? Difficult as they change with each album. And I can't listen to an album straight, I get a headache and have to go do something else.

So my brain kicked me out of sleep rejecting the premise of my dream. Joy and happiness. Back in highschool days, in the 4-H Band, and folk were just milling about. Evidently when things in a dream are even more absurd and annoying than in Real Life my conscious brain kicks in and goes **WOOP WOOP** *YOU ARE DREAMING* and I wake. Ah well, there is some stuff I can do and I've plenty of dry books that should quickly send me to more blissful realms of Dream than that! soundtrack by The Servant. An instrumental version of Cells was used in the trailers for Sin City and the original version was in Transporter 2 I hear. The instrumental version is much better, esp. when matched with Sin City, how a film with pulp roots should look. Larger, grittier, starker than life. Dwight: It's time to prove to your friends that you're worth a damn. Marv:I don't know about you, but I'm havin' a ball.

Is there such a thing as bio-shock? As distinct from plain ole' Future-Shock? This follows from my recent examination of Transhumanism. First off, Technology has been with us almost from the start and we've been affecting our environment almost as if not as much as or more than we've been affected by it from the start. I've found and to be useful in the past in general, and both are well thought out individuals. A recent post by makes a good point and has been helpful in regards to my understanding of Transhumanism. Some quotes from that entry: "Taking that all that into consideration, I was constantly looking forways to hide the fact that transhumanism is basically about advocatinghigh-tech luxury goods as if they were as important as clean water." (quoting malek777) "Trying to explain it all at once just frightens people. A piece at atime, and the whole world will be transformed for the better." Transhuman Space I think is just too big a chunk all at once and makes a lot of assumptions, perhaps valid, but definitely towards a pre-determined goal. I think I'd enjoy before the current year in the setting or further along the timeline better. For example Cyberpunk I get, and The (not so) Far Future. Perhaps I really should pick up Transhuman Space's Broken Dreams and Toxic Memes books at some point for the less polished side of Transhuman Space, but I think I'd prefer to pick up non-gaming books first, even novels. Gaming books, esp. ones like most SJG ones, can be very good but they are just gaming books and gaming is well, gaming. Oh and kudos to Semagic, it really makes posting to LJ easy. I doubt I'd be posting to LJ again without it. (edit: Also a focus on gadgets, gear, and just STUFF in TS. Consumerization of the body. That's part of it I think. Likely unintended but that's how it tends to come out for me and gets in the way of actually getting to the underlying bits)

I keep seeing these commercials for a dragonslayer Sci-Fi channel event thing, billed as being before Lord of the Rings or Narnia but without naming the source. So I was thinking, it looks kinda like the Lord of the Rings movies meet Beowulf. Which rules out Conan and the rest of Sword & Sorcery, too epic and it's unnamed. Maybe one of Lin Carter or L. Sprague de Camp's fantasy or pseudo-historical series perhaps but even though they're best known these days in fandom for their hatchet edit job on Robert E. Howard's works they are also known for several good series of their own. Carter did get a bit derivative and often wrote to patch "holes" in another authors work that were best left unpatched but he was a good promoter and editor of genre fiction. Even though both are dead I'd say their name would be attached to any adaptation of their original work and rightly so. So I was thinking, *can't* be William Morris, Lord Dunsany, or T.H. White can it? I've not really read any William Morris fantasy but IIRC it's very fairy high fantasy stuff. Lord Dunsany was big into dream and knights and pseudo-historicals and gods. Not down in the dirt dragon slaying. Either are likely to have their name attached to any adaptation of their works. T.H. White? Possible, but The Once & Future King is clearly Arthurian and would have been promoted as T.H. White's Arthurian Must See or something. So no author mentioned or original work(s) cited. Went to http://www.scifi.com/darkkingdom/ found http://www.scifi.com/darkkingdom/about/index.html and lo and behold it's the Nibelungenlied! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nibelung http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nibelungenlied http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0387541/ Which is far earlier than either Lord of the Rings or Narnia, being a series of early medieval German epics. Best known in Wagner's Ring opera cycle and an inspiration for a certain ring (among other things) in Tolkein's works. Think Beowulf except less savage and more mythical/fantastic and kingly or a more primal Lord of the Rings. I may still have a copy of this somewhere, likely a used Penguin edition bought at a book sale, but I never got far. Maybe it was the translation, maybe it was just hard going. The story has lots of neat bits though, lots of plotting, feuds, fighting, and magic treasure. And at least one big dragon. I'm not sure why Dark Kingdom was chosen. Maybe anything with Ring in the title as a fantasy is too close for Tolkein film rights lawyers. It's "Ring of the Nibelungs" at IMDB.com, Kingdom in Twilight (Germany) (working title), Nibelungen, Die (Germany), The Ring (Germany) (working title), and The Sword of Xanten (UK) (theatrical title). ??? My guess for why Dark Kingdom is it's from the working title Kingdom in Twilight, which sounds better and more epic than the too short and unimaginative Dark Kingdom. This *is* the Sci-Fi Channel though, so I'm not too surprised and it could be worse. Dark Kingdom doesn't look like it was made for the Sci-Fi Channel and it has to be better than the stunningly bad "Lets put every recent WWII portrayal cliche, add more dirt and men crying, then make it into a disaster flick" recent Sci-Fi Channel War of the Worlds flick. I hate to say it, but Dark Kingdom COULD be cool. And it has Alicia Witt, a favorite redheaded actress of mine who often goes for quirky parts, in it. ^^

The current state of QLI. Or how it really was April Fools after all. I'm one of the schlubs who preordered 1248 (to help it get published quicker) for $30 ($10 refunded if 1248 not published and someone's able to pay it) oh 2 years+ ago now and then joined the Moot (to help playtest stuff to help get it out the door faster too) as a Knight for $15 for one year. No 1248 release still and none of the other books in playtest aside from Gateway have been released and my Moot subscription should have expired back in early June. So far nobody's account has expired and no notices have been sent. According to Alliance Games (they're the main game distributor for my FLGS) both the T20 core book and Traveller's Aide#1 are out of stock and have been for some months now, and they are what I consider the two essential books to run the game with. Finally Phil Reed, of many quality printed and PDF rpg products, is wondering where QLI has gone...again. It's one thing to neglect shipping out and/or delivering pdfs of your own products, but QLI offers PDFs from several other companies through its online store. This is not the first time Hunter has gone completely "off the grid" for months at a time (third?). For those who would suggest something like that I should "be supportive of QLI and reduce my own personal stress load" and not "nut up over it and increase the stress on Hunter, thereby making it more likely I will never get what I want because he just decides to forget it" I'm taking a third option, forgetting it and forgetting both QLI, Avenger, and FFE (I'll just say T5 looks like no improvement over T4, the playtest is running out of time fast with no sign of a real playtest, and I really don't care at this point). I have enough Traveller material from QLI and GDW/FFE already and I'm not running or playing in a Traveller game right now. I did put in a gaming order with the FLGS for GURPS Traveller: Interstellar Wars as it's quality material (I sat in on the playtest though was unable to really contribute to it) and set in an earlier period when people from Earth aren't Racist Loonies. I also plan on snapping up a few choice titles from GT for GURPS 3e from the Warehouse 23 sale before they go totally out of print. Steve Jackson Games, though not without their own eccentricities and errors, are a 20+ year old gaming company for good reason. I'm not interested in Avenger either as it's two of the people who work with/for QLI and who haven't been any better at professional responses. Doesn't help that from the way the thread reads that they know his phone number but won't call him; though if they're trying to sever ties for the non-QLI owned material that was "under development" at QLI I guess I can see that. They seem aware of how to protect their work and cover at least some of their collective hindparts, so at least there's that. Avenger's ramping up to be handled by Comstar Games. I know of them as the people who split from Seraphim Guard a while back when HeartQuest 2 was coming out in print. Comstar Games (I don't follow Comstar Media) does Fudge stuff (mainly bits split off from Heartquest), some Action! and d20 stuff, and CG PDF miniatures of Anime Girls and Superheroes. Yes that's right, Traveller is now being published alongside computer miniatures of anime girls, Bishi Mecha Boys, and Bishoujo Girls. Kawaii? T.T Which is why I'm currently listening to a SPEED j-pop song. Somehow 13 year olds chirping to backing instruments that don't quite add up* fits. >__< * to be fair the album isn't *that bad* for what it is, just a few songs really make one cringe; and I got it on a whim for dirt cheap at a used book store, about 1/5 the import price so it's easliy resellable

From a tip I checked out the latest from Azumanga Daioh's creator Azuma Kiyohiko, Yotsuba&! volume 1 from ADV Managa. Very funny, very cute, very charming. The manga's tagline is "Enjoy Everything". The format is also more like a traditional manga as opposed to Daioh's 'comic strip' format and has longer stories. The main character is a cute kid who's kinda a combination of the short younger kid from Daioh with Osaka. In otherwords, she's short, inquisitive, and spacey. She also tends to get words wrong. From the translation notes Yotsuba& is also how the title is spelled in Japan and comes from Yotsubato, with Yotsuba meaning 'Four Leaf' (as in clover), the main character Yotsuba having green hair with four pigtails like a 4 leafed clover, and To as in 'with' or 'and', so 'and' becomes &. Yotsuba&! Very fun cast with Yotsuba on summer vacation with her Dad, the nextdoor family with three daughters, "Jumbo" (a friend of Yotsuba's dad) and Yotsuba's imagination. A different dynamic than Daioh with a smaller cast and it's good and funny to see the interaction between differing ages in a less formal setting than school or a school class and teachers. Yotsuba learns to swing, gets locked out, is afraid of air conditioners, goes shopping at a department store, and catches cicadas! So far it's very good and I look forward to volume 2, where Yotsuba learns to draw and watches gangster movies. ^__^ No real extras aside from a single page of translation notes (which may or may not be a good thing; I am getting used to having at least a list of common 'sound' phrases) and one non-glossy page in color of clouds and "to be continued". Still a very enjoyable read at list price. This falls under the category of "wholesome" entertainment for all ages in a Charlie Brown sort of way, similar to Daioh, and both works have some echoes of Charles Schultz and similar classic comicstrip artists in style. Unlike Daioh I find myself wanting to watch an anime based on this, to hear how the characters are voiced and how they move. Daioh for some reason I picture as being very much like the manga and not really adding much to it but Yotsuba&! might bring a depth or different view to the manga. AFAIK there's no such anime yet. No reliable website that I can find that doesn't spoil the series and/or is only in Japanese. ADV Films site is a glorified catalog these days and I can't even find Yotsuba&! on it, even just a catalog listing let alone a series overview. >.< For now this will have to do. Sorry folks. On a sidenote, likely due to what looks like the exact same color green hair, I'm reminded of some other manga/anime series. It had an older girl, who may have been a robot, and all I remember from reading about it / websites is a lighthouse type house, a Vespa like scooter, going shopping, and a storm. AFAIK it's never been released in the US.

Foot traffic not related to authority type vehicles seems to have a good amount of people on bicycles.

Time for dinner. Brunch was good but a while ago now. I really should take a break from all this for at least a full day or I'll still feel blah Tuesday.

Been fighting a cold most of this week so have been out of things and not watching news. Survival of New Orleans blog (originally from SJG's Daily Illuminator good radio station in the area (WWL) So far it looks like they haven't been woken up by the early morning explosions near the river or they've been to busy to post. My guess is either something just exploded due to damage or someone got stupid/smart. Whatever the cause it's certainly gotten attention from the major news networks. pity this busy monster, manunkind, not. Progress is a comfortable disease: - E. E. Cummings yep, time to actually read The Dark Barbarian: The Writings of Robert E Howard : A Critical Anthology and order from the University of Nebraska Press' The Works of Robert E. Howard series. I don't care much for the "pure" barbarian in civilization or the "noble savage"* in art and literature but I do have to wonder, what if anything has changed? The veneer of society sloughed off and thrown aside to reveal the lurking hindbrain underneath. Is it the scale, the modern interdependence on energy and disposable machine made goods, the physical location, the seemingly uncoordinated response efforts, or lack of enough facilities and planning to evacuate everyone but those who wanted to stay behind and reap the whirlwind? Is this what modern cities do to humans collectively? Is the situation in New Orleans the norm, just for the modern age or has this always occurred? I don't know and am interested in finding out. I know society breaks down under certain situations but it seems like the reaction isn't a constant given. Maybe it's just that we can show it in realtime instead of impressions later from memory, like the Donner Party. The reaction goes beyond what I would have expected even from a major populated area. Pull the cord, stop the supplies, watch society crumble. It's odd to me since I live in a far less populated area with regular weather problems (mainly winter but an area nearby severely floods at least once in year). Granted we've never had a mandatory evacuation. Still. My prayers go to those affected by this. Welcome to humanity at both its worst and its best. Hats off, stomped to the ground, and burnt. Gloves to the ground, canes broken in twain. * note: I don't hold to either Howard or Lovecraft's racism; they were individuals and of a different time; their opinions are their own, just as I hold mine. But more on that later. P.S. song title should be "Counting Bodies Like Sheep To The Rhythm Of The War Drums"; LJ or Semagic must truncate after a certain # of characters :(
